description: From Middle English deciden, from Old French decider, from Latin dēcīdere, infinitive of dēcīdō (“cut off, decide”), from dē (“down from”) + caedō (“cut”).

verbs.description: decide (third-person singular simple present decides, present participle deciding, simple past and past participle decided)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) to resolve (a contest, problem, dispute, etc.); to choose, determine, or settle
examples: The election will be decided on foreign policies.
We must decide our next move.
Her last-minute goal decided the game.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) to make a judgment, especially after deliberation
examples: You must decide between good and evil.
I have decided that it is healthier to walk to work.

entries.meaning: (transitive) to cause someone to come to a decision
examples: It decides me to look into the matter, for if it is worth anyone's while to take so much trouble, there must be something in it.
Our seat denies us traffic here; / The sea, too near, decides us from the rest.
